Key Arguments: The bill violates freedom of speech.
No authority can definitively determine what is true or false.
Delegating legislative power to private entities is unconstitutional.
The bill infringes on the implied constitutional freedom of political communication.
The bill creates unequal classes of citizens regarding information dissemination.
The internet is a democratic tool that should not be restricted.
Excessive fines on digital services will restrict freedom of speech.
The bill targets not only false information but also potentially misleading information.
The government should not have sole authority to determine truth.
Main Themes: Role of the Internet in Public Discourse
Notable Quotes: I firmly believe that this bill is a direct violation of our freedom of speech.
No authority, body, organization or person possesses the wisdom to discern what is true or untrue.
This bill poses a significant risk to the free expression of ordinary people, causing disproportionate harm to their ability to engage in meaningful discussions.
This style of government undermines trust, cooperation, and the free flow of information, reflecting a style of government that is reminiscent of the Soviet Union.
